nodes.text: The empirical and methodological contributions of David Card, Joshua Angrist, and Guido Imbens transformed modern applied microeconomics by promoting a design-based approach to causal inference and formalizing the interpretation of instrumental variables with the local average treatment effect (LATE)
Design-based approach: empirical studies should emphasize explicit research design that leverages natural experiments or randomized variation to create credible treatment and control comparisons

LATE and potential outcomes framework: instrumental variables under random assignment, exclusion, monotonicity, and relevance identify a local average treatment effect for compliers rather than a population average
Design-based emphasis plus formal IV results changed empirical practice: more natural experiments, focused robustness checks, and clearer separation of internal versus external validity

Selection challenge and empirical failures motivated the shift: observational methods often failed to reproduce experimental estimates (e.g., LaLonde 1986), showing model-based corrections and richer microdata alone were insufficient
Card and colleagues advocated constructing plausible comparison groups and exploiting natural shocks or institutional quirks rather than relying solely on parametric selection models

Empirical example — Mariel boatlift (Card 1990): large unexpected Cuban inflow to Miami produced little effect on native wages and employment when compared to similar cities, illustrating natural-experiment design and counterintuitive causal evidence

Empirical example — New Jersey minimum wage (Card and Krueger 1994): a 1992 survey-based difference-in-differences comparison with Pennsylvania found no employment decline in fast-food restaurants despite large wage increases

Empirical example — Quarter-of-birth instrument (Angrist and Krueger 1991): season of birth affects compulsory schooling exposure and provides IV variation showing about 0.1 year schooling difference and implying a roughly 10% returns-to-schooling estimate for compliers

Empirical example — Draft lottery (Angrist 1990): randomly assigned draft lottery numbers serve as an instrument for military service and IV estimates show a negative earnings effect of service for compliers

Formalization: potential outcomes and LATE clarify that IV estimates identify the average treatment effect for compliers, highlighting treatment effect heterogeneity and the limited external validity of some instruments

Implication for interpretation: an instrument that induces narrow variation (e.g., quarter-of-birth, draft eligibility) identifies effects for a specific subpopulation of compliers and may not generalize without further structural assumptions or additional designs

Methodological extensions: the LATE/potential outcomes approach connects to and clarifies regression discontinuity, fuzzy RD, regression kink, multi-valued treatments (ACR), quantile IV, and marginal treatment effect frameworks

Consequence: the combined empirical and methodological work spurred large literatures on immigration effects, minimum wage and monopsony, returns to schooling, and mechanisms and heterogeneity across contexts

Limitation: design-based studies often trade breadth for internal credibility — clear internal validity may come at the cost of external validity and scope, requiring model-based extrapolation or complementary evidence

Conclusion: by centering research design and clarifying IV interpretation, Card, Angrist, and Imbens strengthened empirical economics' scientific foundations and enabled more transparent, replicable causal analysis
